docs.lead_paragraph: House Democratic leaders signaled Tuesday that they were prepared to make several changes to the health care bill to satisfy abortion opponents, including many Democrats, who have threatened to block it. The opponents insist that tax dollars not pay for health insurance that would cover abortion. That could be tricky, given that the bill would provide hundreds of billions of dollars in federal subsidies to help moderate-income Americans buy insurance.

byline.original: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

docs.abstract: As entrepreneurs gave their views on health care reform before a Senate committee, they didn't always keep to the script the Democrats had written for the day.

docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional Democrats and the White House seem increasingly nervous about the prospect that major health care legislation will not be completed by the end of this year.

headline.main: Democrats' Fear: No Health Bill in 2009

docs.abstract: Congressional Democrats and the White House are starting to worry that major health care legislation will not be completed by the end of the year.

docs.lead_paragraph: Correction| 6:13 p.m., Nov. 5 An earlier version of this article gave the wrong age for the Urban League. It has been corrected below.

headline.main: Civil Rights Groups Push for Public Option

docs.abstract: The N.A.A.C.P. and more than 50 other civil rights groups plan to unveil a "war room'' in Washington on Thursday to push for a government-run health plan.
docs.snippet: The N.A.A.C.P. and more than 50 other civil rights groups plan to unveil a "war room'' in Washington on Thursday to push for a government-run health plan.

docs.lead_paragraph: Struggling to finish their big health care legislation, House Democratic leaders signaled Tuesday that they were prepared to make several changes to the bill to satisfy abortion opponents, including many Democrats, who had threatened to block it.

headline.main: Democrats Near Deal on Abortion Coverage

docs.abstract: House Democratic leaders signaled willingness to change the health care bill to satisfy abortion opponents, including many Democrats, who had threatened to block it.

byline.original: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

docs.lead_paragraph: Maybe the insurance companies have less to fear from a government-run health plan than they think.

headline.main: Analyst: Insurers Needn't Fear Public Option

docs.abstract: A Wall Street analyst says a government-run insurance plan might resemble a non-profit Blue Cross plan -- which is why private insurers should not fear it.
docs.snippet: A Wall Street analyst says a government-run insurance plan might resemble a non-profit Blue Cross plan -- which is why private insurers should not fear it.

docs.lead_paragraph: On Slate, Tracie McMillan argues that while small farms might have a romantic appeal to those who believe in sustainable agriculture, a worker might be better off at a large-scale farm.

headline.main: A Good Word for Big Farms

docs.abstract: Agricultural workers may be better off at large-scale farms than at small ones.
docs.snippet: Agricultural workers may be better off at large-scale farms than at small ones.

docs.lead_paragraph: William Hsiao is a professor of economics at the Harvard School of Public Health and co-author of the 2004 book "Getting Health Reform Right." He served as a health care adviser to the Taiwan government in the 1990s, when officials decided to reform that country's health care system and to introduce universal coverage. He spoke with Anne Underwood, a freelance writer.
docs.abstract: Taiwan implemented a Canadian-style single-payer system in less than a year.
docs.snippet: Taiwan implemented a Canadian-style single-payer system in less than a year.

docs.lead_paragraph: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appear in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

docs.lead_paragraph: The health insurance industry likes to cite figures showing that 87 cents of every dollar in premiums is spent on medical claims. But a new Senate analysis suggests that for-profit insurance companies are spending much less than that, especially for policies sold to individuals and small businesses. Read Reed Abelson's report, in Business Day.

headline.main: Questioning Insurers' Payments for Medical Claims

docs.abstract: The health insurance industry likes to cite figures showing that 87 cents of every dollar in premiums is spent on medical claims. But a new Senate analysis suggests that for-profit insurance companies are spending much less.
docs.snippet: The health insurance industry likes to cite figures showing that 87 cents of every dollar in premiums is spent on medical claims. But a new Senate analysis suggests that for-profit insurance companies are spending much less.
